quiz.title: Physics Grade 11: Kinematics on Inclined Surfaces
quiz.subtitle: Unit 2 Quiz 4: Motion on Inclined Planes (10 Problems)
quiz.subject: Physics

questions.question: A skier starts from rest at the top of a 20° slope and accelerates uniformly down the incline. If she reaches a speed of 15 m/s after traveling 40 m down the slope, what is her acceleration? (Assume no friction)
A block is projected up a 25° incline with an initial speed of 8.0 m/s. The coefficient of kinetic friction is $\mu_k = 0.20$. How far up the incline does it travel before coming to rest?
questions.explanation: Acceleration up incline: $a = -g(\sin\theta + \mu_k \cos\theta) = -9.8(0.4226 + 0.1813) = -5.918$ m/s². Distance: $0 = 8.0^2 + 2(-5.918)d \rightarrow d = 64/11.836 \approx 5.41$ m.

questions.question: A box slides down a 30° incline from rest. If it takes 4.0 s to reach the bottom, what is the length of the incline? (Assume no friction)
A car coasts up a 10° hill with an initial speed of 20 m/s. Ignoring friction and air resistance, how far up the hill does it travel before stopping?
A snowboarder starts from rest at the top of a 35° slope that is 50 m long. If there's no friction, what is his speed at the bottom?
questions.explanation: Acceleration $a = g \sin\theta = 5.621$ m/s². Speed: $v^2 = 0 + 2 \times 5.621 \times 50 = 562.1 \rightarrow v \approx 23.7$ m/s.

questions.question: A block is given an initial push up a 40° incline with speed 6.0 m/s. The coefficient of kinetic friction is $\mu_k = 0.30$. How long does it take to return to its starting point?
questions.explanation: Up: $a_{\text{up}} = -g(\sin\theta + \mu_k \cos\theta) = -8.551$ m/s², $t_{\text{up}} \approx 0.7015$ s, $d \approx 2.105$ m. Down: $a_{\text{down}} = g(\sin\theta - \mu_k \cos\theta) = 4.047$ m/s², $t_{\text{down}} \approx 1.020$ s. Total $\approx 1.72$ s.

questions.question: A ball is rolled up a 15° incline with an initial speed of 12 m/s. How much time elapses before it returns to its starting point? (Assume no friction)
questions.explanation: Acceleration magnitude $a = g \sin\theta = 2.536$ m/s². Time up: $t_{\text{up}} = 12/2.536 \approx 4.731$ s. Total time $= 2 \times t_{\text{up}} \approx 9.46$ s.

questions.question: A crate slides down a 28° incline starting from rest. If the incline is 12 m long and it takes 3.5 s to reach the bottom, what is the coefficient of kinetic friction?
questions.explanation: First find acceleration: $12 = 0.5 \times a \times (3.5)^2 \rightarrow a \approx 1.959$ m/s². Then $1.959 = 9.8(\sin 28° - \mu_k \cos 28°) \rightarrow \mu_k \approx 0.305$.

questions.question: A skateboarder rolls down a 22° ramp that is 8.0 m long. If he starts from rest and there's no friction, what is his speed at the bottom?
questions.explanation: Acceleration $a = g \sin\theta = 3.671$ m/s². Speed: $v^2 = 0 + 2 \times 3.671 \times 8.0 = 58.736 \rightarrow v \approx 7.66$ m/s.

questions.question: A block is projected up a 32° incline with speed 10 m/s. The coefficient of kinetic friction is $\mu_k = 0.25$. What is its speed when it returns to the starting point?
questions.explanation: Up: $a_{\text{up}} = -g(\sin\theta + \mu_k \cos\theta) \approx -7.271$ m/s², distance $\approx 6.877$ m. Down: $a_{\text{down}} = g(\sin\theta - \mu_k \cos\theta) \approx 3.115$ m/s², $v^2 = 2 \times 3.115 \times 6.877 \approx 42.84 \rightarrow v \approx 6.55$ m/s.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You've mastered kinematics on inclined surfaces with and without friction.
scoreMessages.70: Very good! Solid understanding of inclined plane motion and energy considerations.
scoreMessages.50: Good progress. Practice distinguishing between frictionless and frictional cases.
scoreMessages.0: Review kinematics equations and force components on inclines.
